A topic can be in one of these states:

  • Muted
  • Unmuted
  • Followed
  • Default

When a new topic is created it is in default state.

Now a user can mute/unmute/follow the topic or set it to default.

So what is the difference?

In terms of notifications:

Suppose a new topic is created; for a new message in the topic, it will obey the stream-specific notification settings and global notification settings as fallback to determine -- whether to email/push/desktop/audible notify the user or not.

Now, suppose the user mutes the stream; no notifications for new messages.

If a user still want to get notified visually + email/push/etc notifications for a few of the topics in that stream (not every message in the stream); the user can unmute the topic.

# A normal muted topic. No notifications and unreads hidden.
        MUTED = 1, "Muted topic"

        # This topic will behave like an unmuted topic in an unmuted stream even if it
        # belongs to a muted stream.
        UNMUTED = 2, "Unmuted topic in muted stream"

        # This topic will behave like `UNMUTED`, plus some additional
        # display and/or notifications priority that is TBD and likely to
        # be configurable; see #6027. Not yet implemented.
        FOLLOWED = 3, "Followed topic"

        # Implicitly, if a UserTopic does not exist, the (user, topic)
        # pair should have normal behavior for that (user, stream) pair.

        # We use this in our code to represent the condition in the comment above.
        INHERIT = 0, "User's default policy for the stream."

In an unmuted stream:

  • a topic having "DEFAULT" state has the same behaviour as of a topic having "UNMUTED" state.

So, UNMUTED state has no significance in an unmuted stream.

In a muted stream:

  • a topic having "DEFAULT" state won't receive notifications + faded + not visible in recent conversations etc
  • a topic having "UNMUTED" state will receive notifications + not faded + visible in recent conversations etc
"UNMUTED" state has significance in "muted" streams.

We can say "UNMUTE" is the default in an unmuted stream. (as the DEFAULT and UNMUTE state has the same behaviour in unmuted streams)

But, we can't say "UNMUTE" is the default in a muted stream (both DEFAULT and UNMUTE states behave differently in muted streams)
We don't have to bind UI to how actual logic is done
You have the logic and you have the right to switch state from default to unmuted, but a user doesn't care, for them nothing much changed. The default state is neutral and unmuted too.

Regular state means "Default, I don't care".
And if the topic is muted and I click normal state it means "return it to default and stop being muted"

So, should we show

  • MUTE
  • FOLLOW
  • DEFAULT or regular
    in unmuted stream
  • UNMUTE
  • FOLLOW
  • DEFAULT
    in muted stream

I think it makes sense to not-show the "UNMUTE" option when the stream the topic belongs to is not muted.

This would avoid confusion, because for a user, it only makes sense to UNMUTE a topic when the stream is muted.

Although we have separate values of DEFAULT and UNMUTED in our logic, as Tim pointed out above, topics with any of these values will behave the same in all respects when the stream is not muted.

I think in that case (ie, in a not-muted stream) it makes sense for the UI to not differentiate between these states, and just show a single option of "Regular" in the UI (which will internally store the policy as DEFAULT or INHERIT).

Yeah I think the challenge with collapsing to only 3 states is that if you were to briefly toggle a stream between muted/unmuted, you'd lose the state of whatever topics you'd explicitly unmuted in that stream, which is annoying.

I think a potentially reasonable compromise is that for the common case of a stream that is not muted, we don't display the "unmute topic" option, and we display topics that are unmuted as "default/inherit/normal/regular" in the UI -- but if you re-mute the stream, it'll remember that they had been unmuted (until you change that). And then for a topic in a stream that is muted, we display all 4 options.

@Prakhar Pratyush @Vlad Korobov thoughts on that approach? I think that provides the flexibility to specify all the useful states in all cases, without having a confusing semi-duplicate option being displayed for streams that are not muted.

It will come up only if someone unmuted a previously muted stream where they'd unmuted topics, and I like correctly displaying that unusual state (which only does something if your remute it) in the detailed panel for the issue -- it's much more of a power user place to be.

Actually, you know, that suggests potentially a unifying answer here we could use in both the recipient bars and there:

  • Only display the 4th "unmuted topic" option in streams that are not muted if that's the current value.

This avoids the big design downside of showing this 4th nearly-identical option to users who just are in the normal default state of a normal topic within a normal stream.

So we'd only show it to users if they've done the weird sequence of steps that would have that state, while also avoiding destroying information (by having unmuting a stream clear the "unmuted" state on all topics in the stream).

bell-striked.svg relies on fill-rule: evenodd because the piece with the hole has both its inner and outer paths oriented counterclockwise. Fonts don’t support that; the inner and outer paths need opposite orientation.

Thanks Anders Kaseorg for the insights!

I'm not aware of the fill-rule: evenodd property or the other SVG details you mentioned. So, I'll give it a read, and then let's see if there is a way to improve it.

I think we really ought to look into implementing something like svg-sprite. As I understand it, the main reason to do SVG-to-font conversion is to save on what would be tons of resource requests. There doesn't seem to be any other benefit, and a lot of pain--from issues like this, to having to eyeball through sizing matters, to--as Vlad and I have discovered--apparent rounding errors in the conversion process that can wildly exaggerate minor, otherwise unnoticeable variations in stroke width.
Fonts also don’t have a concept of strokes or stroke-width; we need to convert strokes to paths (previous discussion).
But yeah, something like SVG sprites might be good to investigate. I think we want something with Webpack integration—maybe svg-sprite-loader or unplugin-svg-sprite?

I guess svg-sprite-loader has syntax like this: <svg><use xlink:href="#id"></use></svg>. That one at least feels fairly ugly/arcane.

I think the two motivations we have for the icon font approach are:

  • Avoiding one HTTP request per tiny asset.
  • Having it feel fairly readable, with the syntax we put in templates for using an icon clearly expressing the icon's name.

I guess a bonus is being easy to grep for where one is used, but that's probably hard to avoid.

One possible approach to that ugly syntax would be creating a series of small Handlebars templates, so that we could just call them up to render with the familiar `{{ > some_custom_icon }} syntax, which would be pretty easy to grep for.
